church. its an impressive church, in buda side, in the whole complex of the buda castle, among other monuments, walking from margarita island, it worth to see it

On the hill. Situated on the grand overview location near the Fisherman's Bastion (across the street). Named after a popular Hungarian king. It is a prominent church in the histories of the Hungarian peoples. It is not a cathedral (not that it matters). Very beautiful. Rich decor and statuary.

700yr old church. Built in 1400 Matthias Church is one of the oldest buildings on Castle Hill. It stands prominently next to the Fisherman's bastion in Holy Trinity Square. Entry is 1000Ft. A number of coronations were held here plus the two weddings of King Matthias Corvinus. He ruled from 1458-90 and is a bit of a national hero. Many things are named after him around Budapest and look for his signature "black raven" as you walk around town.

Absolutely beautiful ! . This church really is something special. Beautiful inside and out and definitely worth the money to get inside. One of the prettiest I've visited in Europe. Very busy with tourists so best go early!

Very Cool Church. The visit to the church, as well as Fisherman's Bastion and Castle Hill, make for a great afternoon. Even when compared to some of Europe's larger and more elegant churches, St. Matthias' Church stands out in terms of its uniqueness. It was one of our favorite churches from our our entire trip.

Beautiful and unusual church. The Matthais church is unlike anything you've probably seen before. Yes, it has beautiful religious artifacts but it's the patterns on the walls, pillars, ceiling and floor you'll remember after you've gone. It could easily be overwhelming, but instead it's serene. Be sure to visit the upper level to see the before and after photos of pieces that have been restored.

Spectacular - the best there is in Budapest. Well worth the entrance fee, and make sure you go up and see the exhibits too. It is an absoloutely gorgeous church. The decorations, the frescoes, the ceilings, and I could go on. This was one of my highlights in Europe. It is a top attraction and a must see.

Beware of ticket desk!!!. We went to the Bastion and the Church. The church was beautiful and definitely a must see when you visit Budapest. The Bastion has some great views, but if you have already seen or will see some good views across the city, you may want to skip. In relation to the ticket desk, we asked the guy if we could have tickets to both locations and he said at that point to "go to the church first as it closed at 5," so he knew we were going to both attractions. We got our tickets and our change and the change that he gave us looked like it was a little off, but we continued for a couple of minutes. Then, we looked at our ticket and it was only to one of the attractions. When we went back, the guy claimed he didn't remember us and then charged us again for the Bastion (charged us for one person and gave us two tickets because we complained.). Whether he was dishonest and pocketed 1,000 or whether it was an honest mistake, we will not know. Anyway, moral of the story is to check your tickets and your change when you are still at the ticket desk.

Take your time, it's not an ordinary church. I came many times with friends to see the incredible roof, the outside, but never had time to peak inside. Well, with this church you don't peak, you visit for quite some time because the murals, ceilings, the entire church is gorgeous. And then there is a little museum upstairs. I thought it was expensive (over $5) for a church but this is not an ordinary church, it is truly magnificent.Their website is tricky if you wish to see when it's open or book a guide, you have to browse over the stone roof ornament to see text! Not very customer friendly.
Matthias Church. Well worth the entrance fee to such a stunning church. The amazing stained glass windows, painitings & statues make this the most beautiful church in Buda, if not Budapest.

Glorious church, amazing acoustics. We performed Dvorak's Stabat Mater here on the last leg of our central European tour. Such a beautiful church, even more impressive inside than out. Amazing view of the Danube and the Fishermen's Bastion from here. The audience was very kind and appreciative. It was the perfect place to end our tour.

Beautiful church. This is seen when you take a walking tour of the castle district since it is one of the most imposing buildings out there. The striking feature is the colored tiles on the roof which is unique to certain buildings in Hungary. The church is still undergoing renovationsI did not have time to go inside and the cost is just $5 and yet still people grumble about it. The Hungarian government is having a great debit load and can't afford to pay for all the restorations and this small entry fee will help.There is a Hilton next to it which has a nice old part and a modern part attached to the older section. The modern structure is a monstrosity and is an eyesore in that castle district. The only redeeming feature is the glass windows on its one side that beautifully reflects the Mathias church as shown in my photo.

Beautiful architecture. The outside of the church is beautiful, and the inside is even more so. It's well worth paying the fee to go inside and look at the stunning restoration work they've been doing. A must visit in my opinion.

Pretty from the outside. Ripoff inside. The church from the outside us very pretty. But I do not recommend going inside because you will pay a lot to see a building that is under restoration. Enjoy the views from the outside.

A very beautiful cathedral. The outside of the building is very beautiful and quite impressive. The Inside of the church had very amazing stained glass windows . There were also some lovely statues inside the cathedral. Well worth a visit.

Fairytale Church. This is a stunning church from the outside with an interesting - picturesque colorful tiled roof located on the Buda side of the Danube River, set on Castle Hill. Inside this neo-Gothic church are lovely murals. We noticed on another visit several brides, one coming out of the church with a large procession then another on her way in, must be THE place to get married in Budapest, we understand why as it is a beautiful fairytale church!
Beautiful as usual for a church. Another piece of art! Special because of its history. Wish some of that money had been spent on other more important things!

One of a kind. I think this is the first church I've seen using colorful tiles as the roof, which is unique and pretty. The exterior looks very beautiful. Too bad I couldn't go in because it was already close (after 5 PM). Hopefully better luck next time :D

A Beautiful Church. This cathedral, the site of coronation of the Hapsburgs as Kings of Hungary, has magnificent stained glass windows and vaulted ceilings. It is located on castle hill district and the views of the Danube River from the lookout outside the church is very special.
Mesmerizing church. Very beautifull both in the inside and the outside, though it is kind of small in the inside still worth a visit. outside the church there is a great view of the city.

Should be "#1" In Budapest. If you don't go in this church, you have missed the highlight of Budapest.Restoration is nearly completed, and walking into this austere butter colored church is like unexpectedly falling down the rabbit hole into a kaleidoscope. Every single surface is painted in brilliant color, with a different pattern on every column, arch, vault, even the floor. In fact, the only things not decorated in color are the pews. It is just jaw dropping.Be sure to take the short climb to the museum upstairs, which is tiny, but an interesting display of how certain church items were restored, and how some of the stencil work was done.Just an exquisite place to visit. Instead of spending your money to see Fisherman's Bastion, so you can get fifteen feet higher over the Danube, spend it for the price of admission to Matthias Church. My husband had to drag me out kicking and screaming. Had I known what I was going to see, I would have happily paid two or three times the admission just to help continue the restoration. BTW, tiny church gift shop is totally missing the boat. They could make a fortune selling items with some of the patterns on them-needlepoint kits, scarves, handbags, trays, etc.

Soooo beautiful!!. I love this church!! It is beautiful from the outside, I love every angle!! I think the tiled roof is lovely, and all of the church's architecture is gorgeous. Inside the church is incredible! Although I've been inside several times, it was still amazing to be inside. My teenagers were awed by its beauty. To me, this is an absolute "must-see" when you are visiting Budapest!
Don;t miss!. One of the most beautiful examples of architecture and decoration of a church that I have ever seen. Go in and stare, its beautiful and not one to miss!

One of the most gorgeous churches I've ever seen. It was in the late afternoon that we came to this incredible church, so we couldn't go inside, but the outside was still totally worth the walk! It's absolutely stunning- one of the most beautiful churches I've ever seen. It's colorful tiled roof and Gothic curves will impress you I promise!

superb. Stunning architecture, impressive interior. It's located on the top of the Buda hill, near the Fisherman`s Bastion and the Buda castle. A must see of Budapest! It was worth the visit even if we had to pay a small fee to enter.

Stunning. The church sits on top of Buda hill, only yards away from Fishermans Bastion, and can be seen from almost anywhere in Budapest. It’s a substantial structure, parts of it being around 1000 years old, with a very tall tower, but the eye is immediately drawn by the tiled roof. It’s a riot of brightly coloured tiles forming geometric patterns in yellow, green, orange and others colours.And the use of colour doesn’t stop there. The inside of the church is quite simply stunning. Every single surface is painted and decorated. There are huge frescoes, with the spaces between them filled with geometric patterns, or patterns based on nature. There isn’t a bare surface anywhere inside – the pillars are also decorated. It must rank as one of the most impressive churches anywhere in the world. The first reaction is just to stand and stare at this amazing sight, then start to focus on individual frescoes and areas of decoration to begin to make sense of it all.There are several side chapels, and a small museum housed in an upper level of the church. The entrance fee is around 200 – 300 HUF (less than £1).It’s absolutely a must see sight in Budapest.
Exquisite interiors.. Don't miss going in. Very different from other churches in the style of the rich decorations inside, more mid-eastern than any other in the region, worth the ticket.

The most beautiful church I've ever seen..... The whole area is so interesting with wonderful architecture and plenty of shops. But the church is the show piece. The inside is beyond words to describe...you just have to see it. The entire inside is hand painted in a style I've never seen before in a church. It is simple compared to some of the churches we saw in Germany and Austria but this church is by far the most beautiful. Make it high on you lists of things to see in Budapest!

City tour. We went up castle hill on our city tour and stopped here. It is impressive architecturally with a fine spire and an amazing ceramic roof. The views of the city from outside are also beautiful. Inside it's not the most impressive church in Europe but still worth visiting.

Amazing Interior. As previous reviews rightly pointed out, the interior of the Matthias Church were worth braving the crowds for. In particular, pay attention to the ceilings and the stained glass windows.Of course, these should not be taken to mean the exterior is not beautiful. It is, although the interiors wowed me more.

Exceptional Church. On the castle hill, behind the Fisherman's Bastion stands this beautiful colored structure called the Matthias Church. Its great architecture draws the attention of the visitor's. The interiors of the church are so charming that you get mesmerized. Despite suffering several attacks, this monument stands to be the best.

Worth the Quick Visit. Right next to Hilton on Castle Hill behind Fisherman's Bastion. Worth a quick visit to see the inside including stained glass windows. Went to mass there on Sundau morning - in Hungarian. Excleent picture opportunities inside and out.

Must see sight. The church is named after the popular renaissance king and its official name is Church of our Lady. We went early on a saturday and the church closed before the official 1PM closing time as there was a wedding at the church in the afternoon. The church was destroyed several times and the one you see was rebuilt after WWII.There a lot of cafes and eateries near the fisherman bastion is next to it.

Something else . As Churches go, this is special. The size certainly gives the Matthias Church an advantage however it's really the roof tiling that makes it stand out, coupled with the position it occupies in the city, the views it commands and the history surrounding it. Really worth it.

Beautiful Matthias Church. Budapest, Hungary was the final stop on our Viking Romantic Danube river cruise. Matthias Church on the hill in the Buda section of the city has one of the most beautiful exteriors we saw on our trip. The colorful tiled roof was magnificent. Also called the Church of Our Lady in Buda Castle, it was rebuilt in1896. Definitely a must-see.
Under wraps last time. Now fully restored to its magnificent glory. You must go inside it is worth the entrance fee. The decorated walls and frescoes take your breath away

A lovely church inside & out with vibrant colors, including an unusual tile roof.. My wife & I visited the church as part of a group tour the morning of Saturday 5/10. Having seen a lot of European churches, cathedrals & basilicas, we were not expecting much, but we were pleasantly surprised. The church - along with St. Stephen's Basilica & the Great Synagogue - struck us as one of the "Big Three" of Budapest's religious attractions. Plus the church has the advantage of its location on Castle Hill with terrific views from the adjacent Fisherman's Bastion plus the proximity of many other attractions, shops, & restaurants.The church's tile roof was particularly unusual: very ornamental & colorful with an eye-catching design. The interior was more subdued, but almost as unusual, especially in its arching columns.Be sure you visit!

Ornamental. Very nice church, printed with color pictures of ravens and ornaments. So beautiful and so hungarian!It was a place, where hugarian kings were crowned, so you can see the copy of a pompous crown in a small museum inside the church.

Beautiful!. A beautiful church inside and out. Very ornate and the gallery detailing the restoration works was very interesting. Don't bother getting a combined ticket with the Fisherman's Bastion as the views are better from the cafe in the tower further along.

Busy but Beautiful. One church guard told us to get up there right at 9:00 a.m. before all the tour busses arrive. (Note that they open later on Sundays, or at least they did the Sunday that we were there.) But we decided to slog through it, using the old Rick Steves' tour book to help us. My favorite parts were the upper balcony where I could look over everything, the ornately decorated stairs, the replica of the crown, and the Loreto Chapel. Side down and look up and enjoy the ceiling. Worth the price of admission.

Worth a visit!. This church is beautiful and well worth a visit. The views are fantastic and you can also walk out along the Fisherman's Bastion. The church is worth the price of admission, however do not be duped into paying the additional fee for the Fisherman's Bastion as there is a part of the Bastion - just as good - that can be accessed for free!

Small But Beautiful. Near the Fisherman's Bastion, Matthias Church is a graceful architecture that is a major attraction in the Castle district. Flags inside help to learn about is coronation church for some of the kings of the area. Allow 20 minutes for touring.

Crowds yes, but this Church is worth your time. We visited Matthias Church an we were very glad we did. This Church and the surrounding area with the Fishermen's Bastion and the ruins of the old Monastery (at the Hilton) were amazing even with the crowds. The tile on the Church roof was incredible and the views of the Danube, Buda and Pest below the Bastion were exquisite. Be sure to take the time to see all of the treasures up on the Castle Hill and make sure you have the time to see the Church from the Chain Bridge or the Pest side of the Danube at night for a sight you will never forget.

Beautiful from the outside. I didn't go inside the church, but from the outside it is absolutely beautiful. I love the coloured-tiled roof. It's also right near Fisherman's Bastion and Buda Castle, on the Buda side of the Danube.

Worth your while. The church is both beautiful and extraordinary in its architectural presence, both from the inside and outside. The interior's looks are well different from what you always see in the European churches and while it's unlikely you'll spend there more than half an hour, it's worth to see something so fresh and surprising (while still captivating) in its category.

Interesting but not extraordinary. It is a beautiful place, with beeautiful architecture but it does not worth the money to go inside. It is beautiful inside too but is not extraordinary, not large you can actualy see it in 10 minutes. I have seen lots of churches more beautiful in Vienna, Paris ...without tickets. Paying to go into a church does not sound right, it is only commercial and targeted on tourists. There are other churches in Budapest they ask you to pay for entrance, but we had a nice walk around the Budapest tourist center and discovered beautiful opened churches for everyone.

Beautiful inside and out.... Matthias Church is an eye-catching structure, due to the coloured tiles on the roof. The church has beautiful architecture and it is really lovely inside. It is in a stunning location, with very good views of the Danube and Fisherman's Bastion readily accessed from various locations around the church. In a similar fashion to the offerings at St Stephen's, one can attend organ recitals / concerts at this church at certain times of the year.

Best church of Budapest. If other churches can be the bigger, Mattia's Church is definetely the nicest. So different from any other church in the world, you will not want to leave the square in order not to miss its sight.

That roof is spectacular!. We unfortunately never went in but were told the inside is stunning. We regretted not going in afterwards so if you can spare the extra money then definitely do it.The roof was so intricately beautiful. The whole church exterior was beautiful and well worth a visit :)

Contender for most beautiful church in Budapest. Clearly, of course, it's a fight between this and St. Stephen's, but why don't we just award most beautiful "small church" to Matthias Church and call it good?So much history here. This church has been rebuilt four different times each in different styles and after devastating invasions. It is, writ large, a testimony to the unwillingness of Hungarians to simply "give up." This is the coronation church of the Hungarian monarchy and the Emperor Charles was made Holy Roman Emperor in this church within living memory!Beautiful, worth the price of admission. Give yourself plenty of time to enjoy it and take it all in.
Beautiful. Beautiful Church! Didnt actually go inside the church, it costs I think about 3 euros to enter. But the outside was an absolutely gorgeous neo-gothic style.
Matyas Church. Beautiful Byzantine church above the city and near Fisherman's Bastion. Downside: Larger crowds than most places.

If I Was Catholic.... ...I would attend this church, because of its simplicity. I loved the painted walls everywhere rather than gold leaf. Thankfully, I do not believe in invisible products...but a good visit for architecture indeed. TIP: you must buy the tickets across the street from the church entrance. Don't forget to go upstairs to the museum once inside...included with ticket. Not expensive...$6CAN. Just go.

Average. This church looks beautiful from the outside, especially the roof. It says over here that there isn't a fee but to see the inside of the church, you have to buy a ticket - from my point of view, it was not worth it. I haven't visited a lot of churches, so I don't think myself as an expert : ) and I thought I was comparing it with St. Peter's Basilica and I should not do that, but... I just didn't like it. It was somewhat simple and somewhat tried not to be simple. Confusing.

Imposing building, stunning architecture. This is a great building, with stunning architecture, surrounded by a lovely square and just a stone's throw from St. Stephen's Statue and the Fisherman's Bastion.Although imposing and impressive in the day time, it is even better at night, as it is all lit up and visible even from the Pest side of the river. Due to a service taking place when we there, we were not able to go inside, but by all accounts it is a must see.Whilst St Stephen's Basilica in Pest is probably more well known, this church has just as stunning architecture but of a very different style. Well worth a visit if you appreciate impressive and imposing architecture.

Beautiful Architecture in a Great Location. The Matthias Church beautiful architecture and colored tiles makes it one of the most beautiful Churches in the world; it is surrounded by a beautiful square of the Holy Trinity; full of magnificent statues and overlooking the Fisherman’s Bastion, the Danube and all Pest attractions.We heard that the Church is even more beautiful from inside; however we discovered that tickets are needed to enter the Church; the tickets queue was too long and never ending, so we decided to admire this most beautiful Church from the outside.

A beautiful church from the outside. Matthias Church is very popular with weddings and one was happening the day I wanted to visit. I never got inside, but the outside was very picturesque and right near Fisherman's Bastion.

best church in budapest. I know that St. Stephen's gets more votes - but this church is uniquely Slavic. The wall decorations and the design are a classic east meets west. St Stephen's basilica is larger but it is a neo-classic design that can be seen in any number of churches in Europe. Matthias church is hard core medieval with lots of slavic and aryan symbolry. And the views from the terraces around the church are amazing.
Beautiful church. Absolutely stunning church both inside and outside. Be sure to tour the inside. Great photo op. Be sure to check it out at night as well.
Wonderful Church. A very distinctive piece of architecture, executed in neo-gothic style. Very memorable historical site and one of the symbolic places of the city.
Must see. Very nice place and you have fisherman’s bastion next door. Watch you pockets in this area as it’s very crowded and it’s upscale

Unusual church. The art at Matthias Church is unusual, distinctive, and memorable. There is hardly an us decorated inch of this church that reflects the history and culture of Hungary.
Well worth a visit.
Absolutely beautiful. Beautiful church - beautiful surroundings, an absolute must when in Budapest! Stunning architecture. Highly recommend it.

Beautiful, beautiful church. We absolutely loved this church - it was amazing inside and out. The recently restored roof really adds to the sparkling effect from outside and the beautiful windows were wonderful. Worth seeing!

Worth visiting - if you can stand the tour crowds. This is a beautiful church to visit, as part of a day in Buda taking in the castle/palace, and other attractions on the hill. You have to pay to go in. It really does have marvellous decoration. The only downside is that, understandably enough, it is on every tourist itinerary and organised tours flood the place. When we visited, we could hardly move in there for the crush of tourists, and it was barely possible to sit down and admire the church, as the pews were full of tourists. It feels more like a tourist attraction than a sacred place, and there was little opportunity for quiet contemplation of the beauty of the church. The Fisherman's Bastion is right next to it, and you can visit that at the same time for fantastic views of Budapest.

Top attraction on castle hill.. This is a crazy beautiful church in a beautiful setting. It almost looks unreal with the multi-color roof. Oddly there is a fee to go in. Not used to paying for churches.

This church is really worth a visit. I have been visiting multiple churches during my trips but this Matthias Church made my day. One can see and feel the history including the time of turks in colours and forms. It is in excellent condition. Pay special attention to different kind of windows and notice that this church is not "balances" i.e. left and right sides are not similar. Definitely place to visit.

Brides love it...and so do I!. The church is stunning outside, with so much to see while strolling around the building. It a hot spot for weddings with three brides and grooms on the hill in the hour and a half that we were there. The walkway around the church now has a small fee, so we decided to walk over to the restaurant side of the wall. No fee to access the best pictures of Budapest below, and the espresso was pretty good too. The church only requires a short stop. Maybe 15 minutes. It's better outside.

Beautiful White Church. It's a beautiful White Church impossible to miss when you get closer. You can take tram #16 at Deak Ferenc tér and in a few minutes you arrive there. Leave the tram as soom it finishes going up. This stop serves to go to the castle too. To go back take the same tram across the street.

Well worth a visit. Most spectacular fro the outside, looks like a princess castle in Disney Land. Well worth a visit as is the Fisherman Bastion which is just outside and where you can see spectacular views of the Danube, parliament building and the pest side of the city.

Magnificent Architecture. This church is probably more splendid from the outside with its ornate tower and coloured-tile roof. However, it is well worth a short visit inside and a ‘must see’, whilst in the Buda area of the city. A bonus is that photography is permitted inside. Allow about 30 minutes for inside the church, as part of an overall visit to Buda.

Worth a visit. It is a lovely church to visit. If you go on a Saturday, just take note they close the church at 1pm. Fisherman's Bastion is just outside the church so you can do both places at the one visit.

Very different!. The architecture of this church from the outside really is something special and different. The tiles all over the roofs make it really stand out from others and is definitely worth seeing. The fact that the church has recently finished being cleaned and restored may have taken away some of the old charm but it does make the building very striking! I would recommend you go and at least have a look!

Beautiful. This church is located on Buda Hill - not on the Pest side, as one reviewer said. Having said that, the church itself is lovely and interesting. I have visited several churches/basilicas all over Europe and have to say, I haven't seen that design before. The walls are covered with designs that were painted on, which must have taken hours and hours to complete. It was so interesting to see. My partner and I visited and it was 2400 Forints for the both of us. There was so much to look at both inside and out. You can take pictures inside which was nice, as some churches don't allow this.

Gorgeous, and wonderfully situated as well. The Matthias Church is not a city center cathedral, and should not be compared unfavorably with one. It has a marvelous Castle Hill setting, with the statue of St. Stephen, the architecturally delightful Fisherman’s Bastion, and a great panoramic view of the cityscape and the distant Hungarian Parliament Building just steps away. The exterior of the Matthias Church is truly beautiful, though scaffolding was a distraction during our visit last summer. Inside, there is much to admire, but I must admit that the ingenious off-center stained glass window is what I especially remember. On our way out we saw craftsman working on a restoration, and I would have been happy to linger there to watch had we not been on such a tight schedule.

Must go. It is in front of Fisherman's bastion so it is a must go place. Magnificent outside and also beautiful inside. Ticket includes a visit to an exhibition on the first floor and if you are lucky - I was - there are surprise concerts. It was just unforgettable listening to the voices echoing in the church.

beautiful inside and out. Make sure you check opening hours as we tried to early am and it doesn't open until 1pm on Sundays! Beautiful church inside and out, well worth the fee and take some time to check out all the surrounding attractions - easily accessed.

Gorgeous Facade. One of the most beautiful churches I have ever seen. The facade is that of a gothic style and it is very very interesting, picturesque and gorgeous. I haven't been inside but I am pretty sure it is just as beautiful as the facade.

Nice and close to the castle so take a walk!. It is on the same side of the river like the castle so take a walk to get there. The roof of the church is incredible and very unique-never seen similar. Inside also nice but not sooo amazing. Looks also very nice from the outside at night when it's lightened.
Beautiful art nouveau masterpiece. I could easily have spent hours taking in every detail of this beautiful church. The attention to design detail is incredible.

Must see inside, gorgeous decorations. This is not precisely gothic or can be defined as any period church. This is a blend of east and west when it comes to churches. Although it is seemingly gothic, it has gorgeous decorated paintings inside, reminding me of Turkish mosques. It is a must see.

Worth a look inside, even for those tired of churches. The outside of the church is notable for its colourful tiling, which is nice to look at. Although old most of it was rebuilt after the second world war, as with most things in Budapest apparently. It costs to go inside but I'd say it's worth it even for those not particularly interested in churches and/or tired of seeing another nicely decorated European church. The painting and art on display on every surface of the church's interior is wonderful and exceeds anything I've seen elsewhere. It's nice to wander through.

Best New Year ever!!!. Me and a few of my friends farewelled the 2013 and met the 2014 at the fishermans bastione by the church of our lady. this was by far the best New Year ever... The view is amazing,you seethe whole city of Budapest from up there, the architecture is something you can only hear about in the fairytales... And five hours before midnight you already start seeing fireworks all over the city, when people from different parts of the world start their New Year... It's simply magical...

Marvellous. The place is truly breathtaking with its exteriors and the amazing set of works inside both in its display and the adornments. Yes there is an entrance fee for the place but then the place has so much to offer that I did not mind paying the fee. The place is truly one of the places that must be in every itinerary.

Absolutely amazing. Fabulous from the outside, amazing on the inside. I'm not religious but I was in awe of this building. There was plenty of people about but it didn't feel over crowded and the entrance fee was reasonable. This place is not to be missed and though The Basillica is beautiful, it isn't a patch on this place. Absolutely amazing.
WOW!!. Stunning temple, breathtakingly beautiful. Amazing ceiling and walls. Peaceful and a place of reflection. Entry fee but worth it. Would visit again.

beautiful. so beautiful, it is a must to just enter and admiring around. And there is an interesting story of Virgin Mary sculpture behind the wall. It say no for the fee, but I strongly remember that we are charged for a few Euros to get in.

Beautiful church. Amazing interior wall/ceiling decoration and stained glass windows, quite different to many churches. It has been completely renovated in the last few years. Exterior is also very beautiful with an amazing roof.Outstanding, well worth the trip up to Castle Hill.

Magnificent. Our hotel was right next to this magnificent church. We called in to light a candle for loved ones and had an hour looking around. It is an amazing church with so many beautiful paintings and stained glass. A tranquil place to sit and think. A must visit.

Nice Church. Like the inside of the church. Went with a private guide and was extremely valuable as I was able to learn more about this history. Walking through on your own, would also be cool, but not as good.

A nice church. We saw all of the tourist attractions at the hill, of course including this one. It is a nice church on the outside, we never went inside of it, so can't say anything about that. Nice view from the bastion just outside of the church.
Very Different Church. You can't miss this if you are headed up to the castle hill. Beautiful both inside and out. Very different church.
Impressive. Well worth a visit. Not really up there with the architectural greats but nice. Don't forget to go up the steps to the museum and look over the balcony to the church.

St. Matthias Church - Our favourite church visit in Budapest. One of the top attractions in Budapest is St. Matthias Church (Matyas Templom), found upon Castle Hill in the Buda side of the Danube River. This is a historically important and beautiful church, which has undergone significant restoration in recent years. There is an entry fee (1200ft per adult) which we find reasonable for visit to St. Matthias Church. The church has a long and history, having first begun as a Romanesque style church around 1015. Destroyed by the Mongols in 1242, a new Gothic style church was built in the 13th century. The name St. Matthias was then assumed during the late 15th century, after King Matthias I donated the two towers to the church. Damaged heavily during the Turkish invasion, by 1541 the church had been completely stripped of its identity and served as a mosque during the occupation. Upon the liberation of the city in the late 17th century, the church was resigned in Baroque architectural style which was popular during that time. Later renovations towards the end of 19th century, by Frigyes Shulek, refashioned the church in a Neo-Baroque style while returning some of the church design back to its 13th century Gothic origins. More recent restorations has also been made, allowing you to see St. Matthias in a lovely state and condition. Within the church there are some beautiful and interesting things to see. The inner walls, column, vaulted arches and ceilings have been heavily painted with nice religious images and coloured pattens. Nice stain-glassed windows designed by Schulek and painted by Karoly Lotz can be seen and its worth looking for the Hidden Images of King Louis, which can be spotted near the top of one of the wall columns. We also enjoyed gothic Tomb of King Bela III and Anne de Chatillon as well as the lovely altar area and decorated shire to the Madonna, added by Schulek in 1893. Atop the shrine, you can see a replica of the King Matthias crown, which is best viewed from the upper floor rooms. You can also access the upper floor of the church, via the tower stairs. Here you can see a small Ecclesiastical Art Museum, lovely views of the main body of the church as well as that of Schulek's Madonna and the Hungarian Crown. In addition to visiting the inside of St. Matthias, the exterior of the church is worth viewing as well. There are gargoyles and beautiful, diamond tiled roof of the church that can be seen. The tiled roof, in particular, is highly photogenic. There is a nice Holy Trinity Column in front of the church and an equestrian statue of St. Stephen around back, just in front of the impressive Fisherman's Bastion structure. All are worth seeing, particularly the Fisherman's Bastion and the fine views of the Danube River and cityscape afforded from its hillside position. Overall, we very much enjoyed visiting St. Matthias Church in Budapest. In addition to having a long and interesting history, the church is very well situated upon Castle Hill and a beautiful place to visit. You can easily and conveniently see the church as part of your visit of the Castle District attractions.

Very nice. As part of our day out at Castle Hill we visited the Matthias church. It wasn’t part of our itinerary but since the Church is smack in the middle of all the other sites we thought we should give it a go. The architecture and artifacts make it worth seeing, though it is not as impressive as the Basilica in our view. Was inexpensive to get in to and was another positive experience on Castle hill.

Beautiful church. The Gothic exterior is more recent, but it is still a lovely church. Roof is interesting. Check out the rooster, the moon and sun and raven above you (be nice to play with a child - find the raven Find the sun! -not that they're hidden, but they are way up there). We did not spend much time here because we were on a tour with very limited time. The whole neighborhood deserved more time in my estimation. Touristic, but lovely. Budapest itself was a wonderful surprise and of all the lovely places on the river cruise from Passau onward, the one place I definitely want to revisit.

Stunning, Amazing. Absolutely amazing visit. The church is beautiful on the inside and the outside. Very colourful! One of the most beautiful churches I have seen. Also, the view of the city is stunning.

Stunning!. We love the churches & Cathedrals in Europe, and rarely pass up an opportunity to visit the interior. We find that each one is unique and so very beautiful, each one different than the rest. Matthias Church in the Castle District of Budapest is no exception. It has wonderful, exceptionally vibrant color and contrast in it's pillars of blue and tan and gold ceilings. We happened to catch a small singing group, visiting Budapest for a concert, who chose to break into song ~ well, it was certainly enough to make you catch your breath, those lovely A Cappella voices reaching heaven-ward, amplified by the gracious walls and generous ceilings of this lovely church who have entertained such melodies for centuries. The small entrance fee should not be a deterrent to your visiting this church.
white stone lace! magnificent!. very beautiful church near old city. very impressive gotic architecture but not gloomy as gotic style. it is real white stone lace, very festive!

Stunning!. Beautiful building inside and out. Interesting detail on the reservations that had taken place.Its an interesting comparison with our church's because the colours are as they would have been very vibrant compared to the faded colours we have.

Not the kind of church I was expecting!. This is definitely not the kind of church I was expecting! The colourful tiles are something that I had never seen before in a Western European church and inside the gothic triptychs were also a surprise! Not sure about the mummified hand on display, didn't put any coins inside the slot to see it, it was all too commercial for my taste.

Medieval. A Roman Catholic Church set in a stunning part of the city. I wandered inside with a couple from the group I was in, but soon I separated and lost myself in the incredible beauty of this church. Upstairs you get to see some amazing relics and see the church from a different perspective. The colourful mix of tiles on the roof were enough to draw my interest from the outside, but inside... I had never quite seen a church like it.

Stunning church!. A lot of work has gone on to restore this building, both inside and outside. It is now quite stunning. I have been a few times, including the Latin Mass at 10.00 on a Sunday. The choir were magnificent!

A must for anyone visiting Budapest. This church is one of the places you must visit on the Buda side of the river. If you think it's impressive outside, just wait until you go inside (costs approx £7 for 2 adults). It's been stunningly restored and is quite one of the most beautiful churches we have seen with beautifully painted frescoes, ceiling and pillars. There's an interesting exhibition on the upper level which gives you more information about the history of the church and the restoration process.

Impressive. The church is impressive on both the outside and in! The recently refurbished roof comprises a colourful mix of tiles and gothic styling. The inside is where the real quality comes in though with an amazing set of painted walls, pillars and ceilings. The roof frescos and the level of detail on the refurbished interior are a must see. Be aware that the price has gone up recently to 1200HFt/person.

Best roof in Budapest! :). A very special building with the best roof in Budapest! If you are visiting Budapest, you will undoubtedly visit the Buda castle area - so make sure while you're there that you drop by.

awesome. amazing church right by fishermans bastion which is also fantastic look left upto Margaret island , opposite to the parliament building [ another amazing huge building look right down to Elizabeth bridge. the church has coloured roof tiles as do several other churches which can be seen in the area. huge stained glass windows , intricate tiled floors, ornate coloured pillars . walk around the gallery to get a view of the alter and the scale of the building and the fresco's on the walls .

Like a fairytale. Stunning place, small admission charge but nothing to keep you awake at night. The whole area is stunning and there is a wonderful children's play park hidden away too. However, do keep vigilant as there seemed to be (when we visited anyway) a few people looking for opportunities to take advantage of tourists.

Beautiful. This is one of the most beautiful churches I have ever been into, it is not a big church but the detail inside and out is pure amazing! I would definitely recommend this to anyone visiting Budapest!

stunning. worth every forint paid to get inside, outside was just stunning has been renovated back to glory. inside I have to say is the most amazing interior of a church I have seen, again been renovated and it was just breath taking.
So beautiful. I found this place so breathtaking. I spent the afternoon there and saw the sunset, absolutely worth the visit.

Totally amazing. After walking round Fisherman's Bastion, this is the next stop on your tour of the sights of the city. All though there is a small charge, it is well worth taking the time to go inside.This is the parish church of Our Lady Mary, and was built between the 13th and 15th centuries, it is truly spectacular. In the middle of the square outside is a state of St Stephen on his horse.At the entrance the portal has a beautifully carved door and above is The Rose window, to the left is the Bell Tower which has retained its original Gothic features, and wonderfully decorated stain glass windows.Once inside it is even more amazing - so much to see. Just inside the front door is a Baroque Madonna which is set into the wall of the church. As you walk round you will see the Pulpit which is richly decorated, and has carved stone figures of the four fathers of the church.Walking round there is so much to see and marvel at, do not miss the tomb of King Bela II and Anne de Chatilion - you finish your tour of the church being totally blown away.Nothing else in the city is quite as fabulous as this church.
Magnificent Exterior. I think the exterior view of the church is much more beautiful than its interior.Especially sarounding area and city view is excellent.

Spectacular. The exterior of the Church is pretty amazing, with its beautiful roof and Fisherman's Bastion as a backdrop. The church didn't open until early afternoon and I was so pleased that we lunched and hung around so we could go inside. There was something about this Church that just screamed to come inside.The interior was something else....just amazing and in stark contrast to the exterior. Very different than the many churches and cathedrals I've seen previously and certainly one of the best.

One of the best Churches I've been to in Europe. I highly recommend you pay the slight charge and spend some time in this beautiful church. This church feels welcoming, warming whereas other massive churches cold through their amazing interiors. 1 - 2 hours would be about right.

Sunday Mass. The church is lovely from the outside, with a striking roof. However the renovation inside is amazing. The entire church is painted and it looks as it may have done at its prime. At 10.00 on Sunday they celebrate a mass with terrific chanting. The choir seems to be all female and mainly young and there are about 40 of them. They line up in the aisle about 10 mins. to 12 and then go up the back stairs to the choir loft, by one of the organs. They sound fantastic. My first church service in many years. You can visit at certain hours when there is a fee. That would also be worth the price.

Mathias Church Budapest. I have been here before, but was content with seeing it just from outside, and saw Fisherman's Bastion. But on my next visit here, I happened to go inside, and was just mesmerized by the decorations, and the beauty of the frescoes. Very peaceful, colorful, and it seems you have come an another time. Like many reacted to Churches charging an entrance fee, I don't mind at all. People donate money to churches and other religious places all the time.1000HUF is not much. Note the staircases, altars, and historical relics, take your time and try to absorb.Officially named as the Church of Our Lady, it has been popularly named after King Matthias, who ordered the transformation of its original southern tower. The church was the scene of several coronations, including that of Charles IV in 1916 (the last Habsburg king). It was also the site for King Matthias's two weddings (the first to Catherine of Poděbrady and, after her death, to Beatrice of Naples). During the century and a half of Turkish occupation, the vast majority of its ecclesiastical treasures were shipped to Pressburg (present day Bratislava) and following the capture of Buda in 1541 the church became the city's main mosque. Ornate frescoes that previously adorned the walls of the building were whitewashed and interior furnishings stripped out. Enjoy your visit !
Amazing. Really beatiful church, very different from everything I've ever seen. Very colorful and cheerful.A must see in Budapest.

Learn the history. Understanding the history and importance if any area while traveling will enhance the visit to this beautiful church. The Plague column outside is also worth a visit. Wondering the streets of this mid evil village is worth a day.

Beautiful from outside and breath-taking from the inside. While most visitors of Budapest take a look to the Matthias Church (NOT saint Matthias - our king of the 1400s, Matthias whose portrait you can find on the 1000 Hungarian Forint banknote married twice and had children from other women) from the outside while not too many pay 1000 Forint (app. 3,5 EUR, 5 USD) to get inside. The recently renovated building is really amazing from the inside and one can walk all around, up and down in the church that exhibits few object from the earlier times of the church.Those who like to take in culture and visit churches should not miss either this site or the Saint Stephen Basilica in Budapest.It's a popular place to get married for locals.

A Do Not Miss. If you are like us, you have seen many a cathedral in your time, and you might be tempted to not go here. But this church is like no other we have seen, and we have traveled over most of the world. Every square inch of the church is painted in geometric designs and other artwork. It is an amazing sight. True there is an entrance fee, but it is small, and you are allowed to take all the pictures you want to take. I would suggest raising the ISO on your camera to 1600, as that successfully got me some truly excellent images. I should mention, too, that behind the church is the archways and citadel of the Fisherman's Bastion. Some of that is filled with restaurants and a shop, but there is still much area from which to take magnificent pictures if you are lucky enough to get a sunny morning like we did. Morning is best for pictures there. If you need a bathroom, look across from the arches. There is a restaurant there which allows you to use theirs for the usual small fee. I know of no other available unless you are actually going inside a restaurant to eat.

Amazing!. The interior of this church blew me away! Amazing paintings and stone work. Wonderful historical facts around every corner. The reason for the four stars is the fact that you have to pay to get in.

Pay to Pray? Disappointed :(. I just wanted to go inside to say a prayer of thanks for a safe arrival in Budapest. I don't like the idea of churches charging an entrance fee for believers to go inside and pray! St Stephen Basilica also charges HUF200 which is fine with me but HUF1,000 is too much. The church looks pretty on the outside, though.
Amazing. Church was renewed after a lot of destruction through WW2, it has Gothic type outside, grandiose baroque inside, 3 euros for the entry, definitely worth it! Do it

Beautiful church. The very reasonable cost of admission to the Matyas church is definitely worth paying to see the incredibly decorated interior of the church, matched only by the beautiful roof on the outside. Don't forget to check out the balcony on the North side, which has a gallery of restored treasures of the church, including a replica of the crown jewels.

Lovely. There can be those who see one church and say they have seen them all: there's some truth to that. This church has some interesting history to it (as most sites in Budapest do) and is very pretty on the inside. Worth a stop in if you're a fan.

Great from afar or close up!. Your first view of this church will probably be from the river. Mine was as it was lit up at night and I was floored by that entire hill of beautiful buildings reflected on the water. The next day I walked up the hill and to the cathedral and had a relaxing beer right next to it (with a great view of the city). The cathedral is large and impressive and, although there are prettier churches in Europe, this one is stunning for its placement and size (added by being atop the hill). Photographers be warned, it's actually tough to get a full shot close to it so you are better off using a tripod and a long distance lens.

An exotic beauty. This church is not like other churches, it has a beauty of its own. Its walls, columns and ceiling are completely painted in different colors, patterns, motifs, which gives it a very colorful magnificence.

Too new . It's a very attractive building but it feels like they are trying to force history. The staff were a bit abrupt when we miss read some of the signage (not recommend:s). You do get some great views but it felt like a movie set

A Beauty to visit in Buda.... In the heart of the Buda castle area stands this stunningly beautiful church presents a neo-gothic style, lavishly decorated after being renovated a few times. Believe it or not this church was once a Turkish mosque and during the construction of the mosque a wall collapsed revealing a Madonna Statue. The church today I believe is run by the Jesuits. The ceiling over the alter is a high formed dome, all in a golden colour, delicately designed, get lost looking at the stain glass windows. This Church and the Fishermens bastion are the most beloved sights of the Buda Castle area. Although the highlight of our visit was experiencing the organ concert.

If only one church to visit in Budapest, this is the church.. Though not the biggest church in Budapest, it is the most pretty. The recent renovations and maintenance has allowed the beauty of the church to be shown. The interior is very pretty with nice frieze and the tiles are very unusual as it is a merger between western, eastern Christian design with a hint of ottoman . There is an exhibit on the second floor. Certainly worth a visit.

Do go but go to st stephens too. Very worthwhile visit though cost equivalent of £3 to enter when st stephens is 60p. Amazing architecture in and out. Can get guide if your willing to pay and wait as well.

Very impressive church - well restored. Key points of interest include the Baroque Madonna. Legend has it that this statue was hidden in a wall during the Turkish occupation. It was discovered in 1686 when the church was nearly destroyed. The Turks took this to be a bad omen so they left the rest of the church alone.You can’t miss the distinctive patterned tiled roof.The royal emblem - black raven with a gold ring – is prevalent in a number of places, including on top of one of the church’s spires.Don’t miss the museum on the second floor.A great place for a photo is from the small park to the right of the church.
Pleasant walk from the chain bridge. Picturesque church in the centre of a lively square. Very close to Fisherman's Bastion with wonderful views across the river.

Stunning. Beautiful inside and outThe crisp white stone outside with its colourful roof tiles is sight enough but inside takes your breath away. St Stephens is amazing but opulent and more like other cathedrals this is quite different with every inch of structure painted, walls, pillars and ceilings.Lovely view over city from Fishermans bastion too.Small fee to enter church payable in booth opposite

One of the prettiest church I ever been. With the facade renovated recently, this church is gorgeous. Try to go there at night time as well, it's very very pretty and safe. Inside the church, words won't be enough, just go and have a look.Highly recommended!

Beautiful and worth the visit. Completely renovated and just sparkling limestone outside and fabulous decor inside...well worth the visit...beautiful location overlooking the Danube...definitely visit if you go to Budapest.

Beautiful church. Don't call this St. Matthias Church. Those in Budapest will quickly let you know that he was not a saint. But they are proud of this church and of Matthias himself. He was the first king in Hungary. The church is gorgeous inside and out. Take a look at the stained glass. Of course, the pictures don't do the church justice.In order to have a real appreciation of the church, you should have a guide or a guidebook or research it ahead of time before you leave.

A musical evening. Had an evening in here listening to Organ and Strings music.The music was very good, and the acoustics for such a high building very good.The church it self is well worth a visit as entry is free but by paying for the evening performance one gets the best of both worlds.
lovely. After seeing many churches with lots of gold everywhere it was refreshing to visit Matthias Church with its interior painted in earthy tones. Loved the ceramic tiles on the roof.

Beautiful. From the Zolnay tile roof to the exquisite painted interior this is a beautiful church. It was cleaned and renovated just a couple of years ago so it is quite pristine. The interior is largely painted wood showing ancient heroes, angels, Biblical personae--but in such color combinations and designs--I had never seen anything like it. Its scale, color and impact were clearly the work of one visionary, rather than the cumulation of effort which seems to inform the Basilica.

Church on Castle Hill. Matthias Church is very striking, with its pale stone walls and tracery decorations in contrast with the vivid diamond patterns of its roof tiles. It is very high on the Buda side of the city, from where you have a glorious view of the Parliament below. The ramparts and arches of the Fisherman's Bastion surround the church, to complete the fairytale setting. Buskers and a falconer were part of the festive atmosphere in December. Well worth an hour or so.

Gorgeous and gorgeous again. Being Catholic, I am not a fan for having to pay to get inside a church ( I prefer to give my personal donation inside...) but the beauty of the interior is so gorgeous you are compelled to forget that minor factor (plus the fact that the price is not excessive). Amazing architecture and fabulous designs. A must see on Castle Hill!!

Beautiful building inside and out. This is one of the most beautiful churches I have visited with lovely and interesting decoration. On the outside the roof is a work of art itself. As a non believer I found it well worth a visit. You are allowed upstairs so you get a good view of the decoration on the ceiling and walls. There is a little exhibition about the renovations which is also interesting.

A surprising beauty. With no expectations, we were in the Castle District of Budapest and found ourselves drawn to an incredible architecture. The roof was spectacular, and the setting beautiful. When we went inside, we learned it was Matthias Church, and we were treated at every nave, staircase, and display with serendipity. It is simply a beautiful, tasteful, artistic church. We could not stop taking pictures, hoping to capture the beauty. Of course the photos were pale by comparison. I would count this as one of the top 10 things to see in Budapest, for its sheer beauty.

Beautiful church with exquisite interiors. We managed to make it in time to go. Took an hour inside. The church is really beautiful. The details of the motifs and the statues are really amazing. There's a museum upstairs too.

Breath taking church. I was walking up a street and was not aware of the location of this church but the minute I turned a corner my breath was litteraly lost. The beauty of the church is stunning. The tiled mosaic roof is one of a kind. Unfortunately I did not have a chance to go inside. It is part of the Fisherman's Bastion but definitely worth it's individual praise and time to explore.

Beautiful church. History , local stories , painted walls - inspired by moorish designs , mosaics , lovely stained glass windows . A great place to learn a little of buda s history ,enjoy the art deco murals . Number 16 bus gets you there : )

A must see in Budapest. This church has exceptional architecture. Photos allowed. Must pay to get inside. You can go upstairs and walk through a museum that is fascinating with artifacts from the 1600's. It is breathtaking from upstairs. The staircases and stairwells are ancient. It is a moving historical experience you don't want to miss.

worth to see. The church isn't big - is mid size. I don't know when it was renavated last time. It looked really beautifull. Paintings on the wall, the light inside. One of the nicest churches i have seen ever

Check the opening times before you go. In summer on weekends it's only possible to visit between 0900-1015 so unfortunately I was unable to see the interior. The outside is impressive enough. Spectacular views over the river into Pest. Luckily the exterior is free to wander about.In the area surrounding the church and fisherman's bastion there are entertainers, shops, booksellers, and food stalls.A great little supermarket is across the street as you head to the castle. Best prices I found anywhere for Hungarian chocolate (Tibi brand) and paprika. Plus they sell postcards and stamps.

It is breathtaking inside.. The ticket cost 1000 Huf. It is impossible to express emotions that you have, when you come inside. That is the best church I have ever seen. Also, there is a small museum on the second floor.

Fabulous. This is my first choice out of all the attractions, monuments and museums that we saw in Budapest.A huge renovation project that is just coming to an end has made this church into a magnificent gem. Go upstairs and find the' Royal Oratory' ( in theatre terms it would be the Royal Box !) and look down upon the masses.As yet slightly undiscovered by the hoards - maybe because it does have quite a stiff entrance fee. But do go, it is lovely.

Church on Castle Hill.. Include St. Matthias Church in your visit to Castle Hill. It is on the top, at the opposite end to the castle. The murals and patterns inside the church are very interesting. Food and drinks and are available from the cafes near the church. There are public toilets in the area and some cafes also have toilets for customers.

Matthias - Magnificent!. Our tour group was taken to the Fisherman's Bastion and this wonderful church with its fantastic tiled roof is right there! Yes, repairs and renovations have been underway for some time but I believe these are nearly completed. The church, while not very old, has all the grandeur of a medieval cathedral: soaring columns, beautiful stained glass and marvellous stone work. It is certainly worth a visit. Don't miss it when in Budapest.

Beautiful church. Apparently much of the church has been covered in scaffolding for quite a while as much-needed repairs were completed. We visited just before St. Stephen's Day and found that renovations have been completed, so we got to see the church as it is meant to be seen. It has a fairly small footprint, but is very tall, so you srill get a sense of grandeur. The decorations are lovely and the craftsmanship amazing. This is definitely a gem and worth a visit.

Magnificent Church. When I was here there was considerable renovations going on but I still found the church architecture and decoration to be amazing and worth every moment I spent there. Given the beauty of the church it is quite small as I would only expect that level of craftsmanship in a massive cathedral.

Do Visit.. It was worth the journey and was stunning. I found it hard to take that we had to pay in. (It's a church!) It was covered in scaffolding- and the work has been ongoing for quite some time. Be prepared for that.

Grandiose church. The Matthias Church represents one of the most imposing buildings in the Buda citadel. It really catches your eye when entering the central market square. I also recommend entering it, since the church looks very well on the inside, too. There is a statue of Queen Sissi of Austria and a replica of the Hungarian crown and scepter. I believe most people won't be disappointed by this, unless you don't like churches.

More impressive from the outside. From the inside I found the Matthias Church superb. It is beautiful from the inside too, but not as impressive as from the outside. It is located right near the Fisherman's Bastion which helps the impression it creates a great deal.
Nice but partly covered by scaffolding. A small but beautiful church with colorful roof tiles. Worth having a short visit while you are on your way to the Fishermen's Bastion.
Under Construction. My tour guide told me this is always covered in scaffolding due to construction. When I visited most of the right side was covered. The tiling at the top is beautiful though.

Lovely Church. Located in the castle area with an amazing tiled roof,most of it has been restored and work is ongoing at the moment.very nice interior with a small museum about the restoration.Early morning lots of tour buses arrive so can get very busy, mid afternoon less crowded.

Nice Church. It is by no means a masterpiece of architecture, but it is situated on the beautiful hill overlooking the city. The church itself has a neat tiled roof, and the interior is nicely decorated. If you find yourself at the Fisherman's Bastion, stroll over to Matthias Church; you may be glad you did.

Well worth a visit.. Nice building undergoing some work at present. Beautiful tiled roof. Worth the 1000 forint entry fee which includes being able to take photographs. A must when visiting the castle area.

Pretty sort of church. Interesting church with lots of Gothic-esque details. Don't miss the Madonna on the side by the main doors (not were tourists are entered), we almost missed it. There are also steps to the balcony and a small museum about the restoration, would recommend.

Beautiful Church. It is such a picturesque church, located just beside the Fisherman's bastions and easily approachable by foot or by bus no. 16/16A. The roof is beautiful and colorful and there is an entry to the Church (like all others in Budapest).
Very pretty church. Lovely church, gorgeous detail inside and out. Personally I enjoyed the fisherman's bastion more, but combine the two and enjoy both!

Stunning Stunning and Just Stunning. Its got to be one of the most beautiful churches from the outside I have ever seen. Maybe its because i dont normally see that style of church and the roof with its multi colours was just something i could not stop looking at. Its full of tourists but thats what you would expect, and entering( as everything other church in Budapest) will cost you. Talk a walk on the walkway as you can get lovely views of the city that will take your breath away. There is a little coffee shop you can eat at as well conveniently there.
Amazing and beautiful. Amazing looking church, especially night time. Located in Castle Hill, so lots of other attractions near too. Must be one of the most beautiful churches in Europe?!
Felt like heaven at night. Absolutely GOLDEN at night - didn't go inside, but the exterior of the church itself and its classical courtyards made the walking tour feel as if a trip to the heavens.
Beautiful inside and out. Construction kept is from seeing some portions, but the church is beautiful. Women do need to cover their shoulders.

exquisite church. I loved the exterior of this imposing church with its tall spires and intricate "lace-like" stonework.The coloured roof- tiles are also amazing. The interior left me speechless - beautiful, intricate paintwork and frescoes with gold leaf all over the walls and ceilings. The stained glass windows are also amazing. One of the most beautiful churches I have visited anywhere in the world.

Beautiful even under restoration. We took a quick tour of the church which is under painstaking restoration by highly skilled artists. My favorite part was imagining what it must have been like when the early artists were at work with the master directing so many apprentices toward a beautiful masterpiece. Well worth a quick tour. Be sure to see the unusual round stained glass window at the rear of the church.

Good architecture. Although I am not religious I always like to see good architecture on church. This one is maybe the most beautiful I have seen by now. Originally it was built in Romanesque style but later Goth elements are added. It stands in front of Fishermans Bastion and belongs to the most beautiful area of BUdapest.

Good enough from the outside. This church is beautiful with an amazing roof!! I could have sat all day looking at it. Inside is also very pretty, but I was a little let down, especially as the entrance fee is 1000HUF, a bit too much I think.

Best place to shop souvenirs. I am sure glad the bus took us to the top because it is quite a hike and there is alot to see. But don't miss all the little gift shops after seeing many I think they have the best quality and selection for the $$$$. I bought a piece of art from a little shop in an alley. It is like a Klimpt but made from enamels on glass. I'll put up a picture and more info once I get home.

Young and Beautiful. By European standards this is not an old church. In the late 19th century the Empire had plenty of money and they lavished it on this lovely structure. In the Victorian age they weren't afraid of color and this church is so rich with color it may seem dark to the modern eye. The restoration is bringing the color back and it does the heart good to see such care taken with one more grand church in a city full of grand churches. In the left rear corner of the church as you face the front you will find easy steps up to the gallery which offers fine views of the interior and access to the room where the king would sit. It is well worth the short climb.
Very Nice. The church was lovely to capture pics of it. Its surroundings were beautiful. Great view & performances. We enjoyed the area with ice cream :)

Don't pay for this attraction. My wife and I are theoretically opposed to paying to enter a church. It just doesn't seem right! Instead of paying, we just asked if we could go inside to pray and of course were admitted free of charge (which we did pray, that was not entirely a lie). Of course, we were able to look around the interior of the church but not allowed entry into the museum. Since we did go in to pray, they did not take kindly to our taking photos and talking after we finished our prayers. If you are going to go inside to under the pretense of praying, be covert if you are going to take any photos.

Be Sure to Look at the Unique Roofing Materials. We ate lunch in view of this church, and it is beautiful. It was being worked on but that happens. The roofing material looks like quilts, which made my wife like it even more. This was one of most beautiful buildings on Castle Hill.

A splendid restoration. Exquisite Matyas Templom is being restored to a fair-thee-well, but visitors are still welcome. It's exciting to hear and see the craftsmen at their work! The ornamentation inside this jewel makes it clear that one is not in Paris or any other Western European capitol, but rather at the edge of the Ottoman Empire. In 1541 the Turks converted this church into a mosque; not surprisingly, the frescoes on the walls and pillars resemble Oriental carpets, and details in the chandeliers recall Islamic metalwork. Side chapels contain exquisite altarpieces and tombs of Hungarian kings and queens. When one considers how many invasions, how many bombings this church has sustained, it is clear how much Matyas Church means to the Hungarian people.

Hilton Hotel next to the cathedral--eyesore. I wish I could rate this place higher, however, when we visited, a big part of cathedral was under construction. It is understandable, they need to do some repairs; what I found irritating though, was the fact that they still charged us full admission. The cathedral is beautiful on the outside, unfortunately, next to a very ugly Hilton Hotel, which totally spoils the site.

Spectacular Painted Ceilings. Yes, the exterior was under construction and they were refitting the stained glass windows, but that only made it fascinating to me. I was there on a day when they were passing up the framed stained glass, getting it in order and fitting it into the windows. This let in an abundance of light and may have let us see things that we might not have in the painted ceiling. There are a few items in a small museum upstairs, but you may be challenged to find it as most of one side of the church was partitioned off with plywood! This was my favourite building in Budapest.

Under construction - disappointing. We paid to go into the church, but it is under heavy restoration, so little could be seen and this was very disappointing. A shame that there is no notification of this prior to entering.

Amazing!. It appears that this church is lumped together as an attraction on Castle Hill, but is should be listed on its own as one of the top five things to see in Budapest. I don't usually like to pay to enter a church, but this was worth every bit of the fee. The interior is absolutely stunning. The restoration work going on does not detract from the visit, but adds to it. To see the meticulous efforts of these artists restoring the painting in this church is really interesting. There are some great before and after displays. This church is not to be missed!
well worth the walk (or lift!). lovely views, well worth the walk up, but there is also a lift up too. The Hilton is alsoup there, but not obvious, the church is the predominant attraction.

absolutely stunning. The exterior of this church is magnificent. Also unlike many of the massive beautiful churches in Europe the plaza for this one is such that you can get back far enough to take in the entire structure and also get a great picture. It is also is great condition, it must have been cleaned recently because it is very white. Inside it is beautiful as well. The interior is different from many Catholic churches with the obvious eastern influence, some will like it, some not as my wife for instance prefers The ones in Prague and Vienna for instance. We had read in a guide that there is an audio tour available and there isn't. You buy your ticket just across the plaza, and although they have a book for sale about the church, there was no audio guide.  It's easy to get to, the bus drops you off right in the plaza, the bus stops are marked with a little crown for the castle, and even if you didn't get off the bus circles down to the castle and comes right back up the slope past the church again and stops going each way. There is no tram nor metro stop though, you do have to catch the bus at malostranka. There is an entrance fee, no restrooms that we saw, and it seemed no matter how large the crowd there was ample space to move around as the place is immense. When we were there some of the windows were not stained glass, we asked and the stained glass in i believe only two frames had been removed to be cleaned/repaired and temporarily have clear glass replacing them.

A great visit. I loved seeing the outside of Matthias Church. Very well done, and provides some good photo opportunities. Go later in the day, when it's not as crowded with tourists- you get better views of the church for sure!! I didn't have a chance to go inside unfortunately. I attempted to go to mass but was turned away with no real explanation (I'm not sure if there wasn't a service going on or what) from a somewhat rude lady at the side. If you do want to go for a visit of the interior, tickets are sold across from the church

A great visit to St. Matthias Church [Mátyás-templom]. At St. Matthias Church, get your ticket at the ticket windows across the street. In early 2013, the entrance fee was 1,000 HUF or about $4.25 US. Student, pensioner, and family tickets are also available. When I visited in early March 2013, the interior of the church was almost completely covered in scaffolding. Many areas of the church were undergoing major restoration and/or cleaning. It was interesting to see video cameras and digital cameras set up to record the minute details of paintings, tiles, scroll work, and carvings that need to be replicated. Apparently, there are serious problems with structural integrity, as well as with deterioration of the interior features of the church, which all need immediate attention. You might feel ripped off to pay the price for entry and find the church under restoration, but I thought this added to the experience. Built in 1255, the exterior of the church was restored and renovated many times over the years in whatever architectural style was popular at the time. Every square inch of the interior of this church is covered in fabulous painted decorations. The stained glass windows are gorgeous, especially the famous lamb window in the spiral frame. It’s breathtaking! Originally named The Church of Our Lady, the church has been commonly known as St. Matthias after the 15th-century Hungarian Renaissance king, who paid for construction of the towers and was married in the church. Be sure to check out the exterior roof tiles as you’re leaving. The pattern is amazing!

Worth visiting - impossible to be missed!. Surely it's one of central places in the Castle District! So, visiting this part of Buda, You'll go by this beauty) - simply excellent architectural masterpiece from any place around You observe it!!!

beautiful church, in a beautiful spot in the castle district. Please do not miss to visit this church, every thing -outside and inside- is very well done, with a lot of care ( that was how I felt ). precious articles could be seen where ever you look. In brief I can say that it is a "wonderful" church.

Real Gem of a church.. This church is in the final stages of being restored, as evidenced by the people still hand painting the patterns on the walls. It is without a doubt the most beautiful church we saw on our travels. The walls are painted with various geometric and floral patterns. We wondered if this was the remaining influence of the period when Budapest was controlled by the Turks and this church was converted into a mosque. The designs on the ceiling and walls were incredibly beautiful and a wonderful change from the overly ornate Baroque churches that are common here. Definite inspiration for quilters here! A tip : purchase of a ticket to St Matthias Church includes a discount on the tour of the Hospital in the Rock.

Fantastic despite works.. Yea there is renovation and it can be noisy. On the other hand - not always possible to watch restorers at work and there is still a lot to see. And don't miss looking at the outside from a all the angles!

Incredible!. This church is an iconic landmark in Budapest and definitely warrants a visit. Unfortunately, when we visited it wasn't a sanctuary of peace and tranquility as there are extensive restoration works being out. It was sadly, very noisy but none of this detracts from the stunning beauty of the interior decoration, which must be seen to be believed. There is much to see, but again, during our visit some parts of the church were inaccessible due to works. Do make the short ascent up to the gallery for incredible elevated views of the nave, East End and upper decoration! This church will not fail to impress!

Just spectacular and worth the wait!. Of course, travelling over Easter and wanting to visit churches do not always go hand in hand. Explanations of when it was open were not clear but we got there - and it was well worth the walk. There are few words that can do justice to the exterior and interior of this building - just go and see for yourself. I particularly loved the stained glass window of the deer (on the far left as you go in), information in the gallery area about the renovations and re-constructions and the architecture is just incredible.

Beautiful church, needs some crowd control. This church in the Castle district is currently undergoing major restoration, so you can't see much of the (apparently) beautiful interior. But the authorities still insist on charging the full entry fee. You have to get a ticket from a separate office opposite the main entry door.My visit was spoiled by a couple of tour groups making a nuisance of themselves, something needs to be done about overcrowding. So don't go until the restoration has finished, and try to avoid tour groups by visiting in the late afternoon.

great venue. IT's just so well placed right next to the Fisherman's bastion and the castle that you shouldn't miss it. Inside's good as well, but honestly - nothing extra, except if you're this BIG church freak... In early 2013 it was still under some renovation on the inside, not sure you can enter...
