Beautiful!!! On the outside!. This church is gorgeous!!! It is a must see, especially right as it starts to get dark at dusk. No need to go inside while the restoration is going on!
church (castle area). magnifecent building outside as been completely renivated couldn't see a lot on the inside as it is being renivated but well worth a vist

Can't see through scaffolding. Big restoration going on which made going to this church a huge disappointment. It was interesting to see the actual restoration process and examples of what had been done already but it was difficult to get a picture, impression of the church in all it's glory since there was scaffolding everywhere.It is one extraordinary churches and well worth seeing but while the restoration is fully going on.

Major rip off as building in major renovations as of March 2013. While the exterior of this church is worth to see, the attraction I am writing about is the part where you have to pay to see the interior. As of March 2013, the interior part of the building is undergoing major renovations that seem will take months if not years to finish. 80% of the interior of the church is scaffolds and wooden planks!! But they still are selling tickets (4-5 euros) to go inside the church and do not tell about the renovations when you buy the ticket! I felt completely robbed to have paid to see scaffolds and not have been told about it. Of course its not about the price as it is pretty cheap in euros as are all attractions in Hungary, but its just the wrong thing to do. Ive never written such a harsh review but this one is totally deserved.

We went - it was closed! Nobody told us first!. The Basilica is being renovated - but I didn't like the door being closed in our faces when we were trying to just ask a few questions. I understand it must be a pain in the backside for the people running the place but a few BIG SIGNS dotted around saying 'closed' would be better than letting people schlep all of the way to the top of the hill just to be disappointed, to stand before a rough-pine door next to a tiny sign that says 'NO ENTRY TO TOURISTS". Instead they wanted us to go to the Museum down the road.

Amazing building, but full of scaffolding. I don't object to paying to see churches but I do when I am not told that more than half of the interior is full of scaffold!This wonderful building is being restored painstakingly by artists, and it looks like the work will take a few months if not years. If you're into watching painters work on murals, pay and go. If you wanted a nice interior picture of a huge, airy building, ask whether the restoration is finished yet.Make no mistake, when it's finished, this interior will be fantastic but for now, I'd personally settle for (free) views of the exterior.

A stunning church.. The most beautiful church on the Buda part of the city, this beauty dominates the entire area just next to the Buda castle.The church features a stunning design on the outside and lovely interiors as well.Make sure to check out the Hilton next to it. It's as lovely.

Inside being restored; Outside is complete. We viewed on the outside only, since the inside is having heavy restoration (and a 4 Euro entrance fee). The outside is magnificent. So I can't wait to return and see the inside!

Do not go in Spring 2013. Heavy (!) renovation going on inside. It is going to be fantastic, once it is done, but momentarily you will be wasting the entrance fee of 1000 huf. Of the top sights, only the Madonna is viewable, but only from a distance. In short, see the Fisherman's Bastion and look at th church from outside, but do not waste neither money nor time by entering.The 5 of 5 is for not dragging the church down the ranking, as this is only a current matter.

Warning: heavy works in 2013. I have been pretty disappointed at the fact that the church is undergoing very heavy refection work. I could only visit about one third of the nave and the upper gallery. What you can see of the place is absolutely gorgeous, every single inch of stone or plaster being tastefully painted. However, the heavy price fee should be brought down or information concerning the works given at the desk before paying. The whole area around the church is anyway a must-see, chances you'll end up looking down on the Danube from up there.

Fantastic. Despite the renovations going on in the church, this is an amazing place to visit. We arrived in the evening and it was snowing and the church was lit up so it looked truly magical. The museum they have set up looks down and over the restoration work and was really interesting. Well worth a visit.

Want to see when fully restored.. When buying ot tickets we were not aware of the vast restoration taking place inside. After initially being chastised by the staff for not removing my hat we entered the building. Though much is inacessible at present there is still a great deal to see. One tip as you travel through the shop if you wish to buy anything do so then as you do not exit by the shop. On reflection visitors should be advised of the building work but do not let this discourage you.

One to see when restoration is complete.. This only gets a very good because it is a building site. But you can still see what an extraordinary example of Victorian restoration is this extravagantly decorated church. The exhibition in the gallery is superb - informative and not patronising, and in English as well as Hungarian. For any lovers of Victorian stencilling and bold colours, don't miss this church!!

Just for the photo. Go at night if you can the lighting is spectacular and well worth the photo. My advice would be visit during the day and catch a meal in buda at night that way you get to see the uphill area in all its glory in both its guises. Inside is ok.

Half of church is closed for construction. Half of church is closed for construction, which we found out after buying the tickets.. Beautiful church, very colorful and unique.. Just wish it was possible to see more of it

So beautiful! Spend more than an hour there.. It was the most beautiful church I saw so far, even if I'm not so interested of architecture. It has its atmosphere. Take a day to walk along the Matthias Church, and the hill generally, it's really worth it. Colors are amazing, especially on a sunny day.

Partly closed for renovation. This is a beautiful church, which also houses a number of excellent exhibits of historical artefacts associated with the church, royalty and the state.At present the building is undergoing a major renovation project and much of the building is closed, so the entrance ticket only gets you a very small glimpse of what the final majesty will be. I look forward to returning in future once the renovation is completed.

Architecture at its best. The roof, even though it is not the original one it really stays in your mind as a colorful memory. Visiting inside it was a nice experience, nevertheless there can be more info for the english speakers.

Just outside.... Even if the church is in renovation, you are charged the same as when you could get a visit inside, in all its glory...The exterior of the church is impressive and beautiful, but.. that is all!
Viewed at night. We walked past the church during the day and also at night and I have to say it looks better in the evening with all the lights on, such a beautiful church

mass was lovely. I'm not a fan of paying admission to visit a Church and light a candle. I do appreciate the need for upkeep and tourist visits for a fee are an asset. Two sides of the issue of admission.I went to Mass on Sunday. I went in with a local older lady who got off the bus with me. The guy at the door didn't stop me entering with her. Other tourists who said they wanted to go to Mass were denied entry. It's a lovely building but a large part of it is under restoration and closed off. Get their on time for a seat for Mass. You stand at the back and don't see anything otherwise thanks to the restoration.If you need to find a clean free toilet and are dressed properly you can enter the Hilton hotel just down from the Church. Otherwise it's a 150 HUF pay toilet fee at the Castle. Bus 16 takes you to the Church from the Red line metro station. Save your money and forget the expensive funicular route and long line ups for the funicular to get up the hill.

Beautiful building. An absolutely amazing building on the outside. Could not stop taking pictures of it and don't think I missed a single angle.Very dissapointing though when you pay for an entry ticket only to find two thirds of it closed off for restoration and you get to see so little of it. They don't tell you this when you are buying the tickets. Otherwise, well worth the visit.

Extraordinarily beautiful.. Even though there was a tremendous amount of renovation work going on in the interior so that we were not able to see everything, what we could see was amazing. Every inch of plaster is painted - columns, ceiling, walls! It was just gorgeous. And the view from outside is also worth the trip.
Beautiful. It's a very beautiful church. Don't miss it when you visit Buda. It's located near the Fishermen's bastion.

Must see if you are in Budapest. For me the no. 1 place in Budapest.Located right next to the fisherman's bastion lots of people miss out on going inside the church. The beautifully decorated interior with paintings on all of the walls and columns and the stained glass windows are astonishing. A place of Historic value as well since Kings married here, coronations took place and Liszt's famous coronation mess was played here for the first time (There is concerts regularly - great acoustic).

Over half under construction. From the outside, this church has the cutest roof and from the inside its beautiful. It's decorated in a Byzantine style and covered with gold guild. There was a side chapel and upstairs museum that shouldn't be missed. The only bad thing, and the only reason I gave it 3 stars is that over half of it is under construction (inside only) but they don't tell you this until after you've paid full price.

Beautiful. It's beautiful. I recommend going for a service rather than being just a tourist with a camera. And if you do choose to go as just a tourist, please don't go on Sundays and disrupt the Hungarian's service!

Deep white gothic. Matthias temple built in the Gothic Revival styleАrhіtektor Schulek Frigyes 1874-1896. In plan it is of an irregular rectangular shape with a protruding apse. In the south-west corner of the church bell tower was built 80 meters. The church has three naves, the central nave is separated from the lateral rows of three massive columns. The temple has a copy reliquarium reliquary in the shape of the head I Laszlo.
see Fisherman's Bastion review. This is a beautiful site and perhaps not as popular as the Bastion itself. Some of it is being restored so perhaps that is why it was not so crowded.

Beautiful. Different than Western European churches.. There's a lot of restoration going on so a portion of the church is closed. Not only that, the scaffolding is out in plain view, which kind of kills some of the appeal.My favorite part was the spiral staircase going up to the "museum". It's a gorgeous staircase.The "museum" is just some relics. Most of the literature is just about the restorations. For good reading, read the signs downstairs that actually give you some history of be church.The outside is quite pretty as well. The roof "shingles" (if they can be called that) are very unique. They are individually colored hexagons. The detail work at the front archway is really nice as well.It will take you less than 30 minutes to go through the entire place.

Beautiful from the outside but don't pay to enter.... It really is a beautiful church from the outside but they are doing a great deal of work on the inside preventing you from seeing much for the next couple of years. Save your forints for another sight and simply take a couple of pictures from the outside. Enjoy....

Impressive architectural icon. Matyas Templom is an example of what Budapest will resemble once the historic building facades of the city are cleaned and renovated.The Parliament building and several other architectural icons have undergone this process and one can only look forward to the completion of the task for the whole city.Matyas Temlom is a true Gothic building and features the iconic diamond pattern roof tiles that add to the building's uniqueness. The precinct features many other Budapest attractions and should not be missed!

Gorgeous. One of my favorite churches in Europe. This church has a really unique and beautiful style. We didn't go inside, but enjoyed the view and the outside area. There are lots of crowds around, many tour groups and even a wedding party when we went. Worth a visit!

Stunning with a capital S. This Church is going through extensive restoration inside so be prepared to see some worn frescos and the odd workman. The beauty is still very apparent though and the outside has been finished. The stone work outside is intricately carved and just stunning! All of this beauty is finished off with the beautiful Zsolnay tiled roof. Don't miss it!

Worth every penny. Even though the church is undergoing renovations, I still thought that the entrance fee was worth it. The interior was so beautifully decorated and the ceilings were a marvel to look at. I couldn't believe that the walls were all hand painted! My husband really enjoyed the upstairs portion with displays detailing the renovations and the restoration of some of the statues.

Beautiful church. Beautiful church, restored on the outside but still being restored on the inside. This doesn't allow for a full view of the inside, but I recommend going inside nevertheless: you get the impression and ou collaborate with restauration (small entrance fee).

potential to be stunning. From the outside the church is absolutely beautiful. I was warned before I went in that there was a lot of renovation work going on, but chose to buy a ticket anyway and take my chance. I must admit at first I was a little shocked at just how much was closed off, nevertheless I looked around, admired the alter and decor etc did the usual touristy thing. Then I decided to stop and watch the workmen (if only to get my moneys worth!) I watched a man laying tiles on the floor and then realised for the first time what a beautiful tiled floor I had been walking on. I continued to observe the work as I walked round the church and I got out of it what I wanted to get out. I saw a beautiful church that, once the renovation work (paid for I suspect by the entrance fee) has been completed has the potential to be stunning.

Beautiful setting. We took the hop on, hop off bus up to the castle district - got off a stop 11, rather than take the ventricular, The walk is easy and not too steep. The church was not open to the public until the afternoon which was a shame - it was Sunday, so we did not manage to go inside. but it is a beautiful building from the outside. We then walked to see the outside of the castle an easy walk and great views of the city

This is a disgrace!!!. The church is undergoing huge renovation work. You do not realise this until you have paid the admission ticket and entered the church that 2/3rds of the church is not visible because of renovation work . We were shocked to have been charg.ed admission to see ......virtually nothing. When we asked when the church would be visible ,the reply was "possibly next year". There are signs at the cash desk drawing attention to the work in progress but they are not conspicuous and are amongst a host of other notices. When you buy tickets, they do not draw your attention to the situation. After registering our disgust, our admission fee was refunded. If you do pay , ask for a refund . They must learn that a church cannot rip off tourists in this way . Budapest has been a wonderful experience . Even traders in tourist hot-spots do not rip you off and charge fair prices. Marvel at the church's exterior but DO NOT PAY TO GO INSIDE. You have been warned

Don't pay to go inside. do not bother to pay the $5 per person to go inside the church, as it is mostly covered with scaffolding and you can only get a general impression of the decoration. The outside is nice, though

Under renovation August 2012. A beautiful church from the outside especially the roof. But when I visited in August 2012 it was being totally renovated and you couldn't hear yourself think for the noise of jackhammers and workmen. Entrance should have been free because of this but wasn't. Large areas areas of the church interior were hidden from view due to the ongoing work.

Awesome. First the church is very nice and it's been renovated and because of that it is as clean as it can be. Then you have an amazing view to the Peste side that you will be crazy to take lots of pictures. This is on of Budapest attractions that you can't miss.

Most famous & attractive Catholic Church!. Officially named as the Church of Our Lady, it has been popularly named after King Matthias, who ordered the transformation of its original southern tower. The church was the scene of several coronations, including that of Charles IV in 1916 (the last Habsburg king). It was also the site for King Matthias's two weddings.According to church tradition, it was originally built in Romanesque style in 1015. The current building was constructed in the florid late Gothic style in the second half of the 14th century and was extensively restored in the late 19th century. It was the second largest church of medieval Buda and the seventh largest church of medieval Hungarian Kingdom.It is home to the Ecclesiastical Art museum which begins in the medieval crypt and leads up to the St. Stephen Chapel. The gallery contains a number of sacred relics and medieval stone carvings, along with replicas of the Hungarian royal crown and coronation jewels1014 Budapest, Szentháromság tér 2Monday-sunday : 9.am - 5 pm.Sunday , from 1 pm (after mass)

Full price for full service, otherwise .... I would not dare refute remarks of the beauty of this church from the outside. I am one of the many who are smitten. It is undeniably stunning. The architecture of the church is multifaceted showing evidence of diverse influences in it's timeline. I admire the details though it is not as grand as the Milan cathedral. But the tiled roof with diamond patterns, that just makes this church unique, gothic with a twist. The Holy Trinity Statue in front of the church, definitely, is a plus. Inside, unfortunately, is not as captivating. It is currently undergoing renovation and the lack of lighting doesn't aid in fully appreciating the interior. The altar captured my attention for its subdued beauty. It is unlike other typical altars with elaborate decorations. It is interesting to see the restoration process done in the past as part of the exhibit. Due to on-going massive renovation, the entrance fee should have been reduced or perhaps the guide book should have been free. Otherwise, be content with admiring the church from the outside.

Ripping off Unsuspecting Tourists. The church is beautiful on the outside, but it's going through renovation. Everyone who bought their super expensive tickets was disappointing because you can't see anything. We saw a group of people demand their money back and they did get it. Good thing we didn't go inside. Budapest - lower your entrance fees, because tourists won't come back if they are treated like dumb rich Westerners.

Reduced charges due to refurbishment. Amazing interior despite refurbishment.Sriking setting on hill overlooking Danube on hilly Buda side of river. Also visit Buda Castle from here.On all tour bus routes
Crowded and dark. You have to pay an entrance fee in order to visit. Crowded in Summer. The interior is nothing special - but around the church is nice and one has good views on the city.
Dishevelled. Unfortunately the church was undergoing a large amount of restouration work which made it difficult to appreciate it's true beauty.
Beautiful, for the parts we saw - most under construction. This isn't worth paying for to go inside...almost everything but the altar and some side areas is covered up.

Mid-renovation. When I first went to Budapest a few years back, they were working on the roof and so the outside of the church was barely visible. I was pleased to see that the scaffolding had gone this time. On purchasing a ticket nobody told me that the renovations had moved INSIDE... so most of the main part of the church is not visible and is covered in scaffolding as is my curse. However, they totally made up for this by making a route through the church that allowed you to see areas you do not normally see. And so we were able to use the royal stairs up to the balcony, and ended up looking at a little display in the roof before heading back down and out of the church. It was a treat to be able to see these areas, and from these areas you could also see what the workmen were up to. If you're nosey like me then you'll probably quite like this!! I enjoyed being high up, to improve it, they could do with opening up a view point so that you can see the beautiful gingerbread syle roof or perhaps see a bit of Budapest from a different angle.
Dark and under construction. From what we could see, its a beautiful church but so much of it is under construction when we went that it was hardly worth it.
Better stay outside. While it is really impressive from outside, the interior is very simple and not worth paying for it

A must-see place!. The church itself is beautiful but not amazing. However you will see amazing views of city from that area! This place is one that I will recommend people to go to when they visit Budapest.

Church under renovation but beautiful from outside. If you hike upto Buda hill, it would be worth visiting, but do not go there only to see the church as it is under restoration and most of the things are covered in dust. The exterior is beautiful though.

Under restoration. The church is currently undergoing major restoration internally. However, what is visible is very decorative i.e. every surface is covered in some sort of painting/artwork. There is also a small museum inside.

Don't bother during reconstruction. Definitely not worth the money in summer 2012. It is really beautful inside, however, you can only see about 20% of the interior due to renovations. Of course we were told this after we purchased our ticket. Save your money, buy a post card of the inside and look at the exterior.

Caveat emptor. The church interior is undergoing extensive restoration at the moment and it might be fairer of them to tell people that before they pay for admission. Having said that the parts which are visible are impressive.

Very beautiful from outside, but now is being renovated on the inside. Not worth going paying the entrance fee and go inside because most of church's parts are not allowed for the visitors during the renovation.

Great outside - but a building site within.. The building is grat fro the outside, but when we went the majority of the interior was covered in Scaffolding and plastic and it lookis as if it will be there for some time. Its a massive undertaking/ Yet they still charge full price (700HUF), which is a bit of a swizz.

View it from the outside, but don't bother paying to go inside. Matthias church looks really cool. The painting on the roof is unique and a nice part of Castle Hill.However, at the time of our visit, we were told by our walking guides that it was full of scaffolding and not worth going inside (it's way more expensive than St. Stephens Cathedral). Enjoy the free beauty outside and maybe when all of the renovations are finished and the scaffolding is removed, then it will be worthwhile to visit the inside.

Lots of history, visit the upper levels. This church is not the oldest or largest church in Budapest, but is really beautiful. There are a lot of historical artifacts on display in the upstairs gallery, and are worth the time to visit.

The Painted Church. Matyas Templom, on Castle Hill in Budapest, is known as the Painted Church. It is quite a unique structure both inside and out. The outside is covered with colored ceramic tiles. On the inside, the walls, columns, and ceilings are painted. It is a unique church and worth the few hundred forints required to enter it.
Dont pay to go inside. Beautiful on the outside, but don't pay to go inside, it's a giant building site, and there's nothing to see. Been totally stripped out.

from far visible. Being renovated , but the outsides already looks beautiful.Especially the roof with the colored roof tiles are impressive in the sunshine.Due to the renovation we haven't been inside, because there was only a very small entrance and a large queue. On the square in front of the church coachmen are waiting with their horsesto take you for a trip, but ............only a few steps away is the Fishermen's Bastion.

A wonderful building with most of its beauty hidden. A recommended place to visit, but the fact that so much restoration and renovation work was under way meant that the vast majority of the building was inaccessible to us - and a charge was still levied.
Renovation. Unfortunately, in April 2012 it was still renovated, so you can look only from outside. And because its maybe the best from castle hill, its pretty disappointing...

A big disappointment!. A big disappointment! The curch is undergoing a complete renovation, but is still open to visitors. But you can only access a very, very small part of the curch.Full entrance fee was charged.
One of our Church which we,re Proud of. This is a huge gothic styled church whith wonderfully experienced koncerts in it by organ and choir musics. It is also an ancient monument.

Gorgeous!. The church was under renovation when we visited, but still gorgeous. Different from other churches you see in places like Paris and Florence. The paintings are beautiful and the church has a fun story.
beautiful gothic style church. this beautiful gothic style church sits atop a hill looking over the danube.
Fabulous!. Amazing church - pay to go inside it is really lovely!

Renovations. 1000 HUF entry per adult. The exterior of the church is worth the climb up the hill alone, but the interior is a mess. You basically walk into a construction site (but not in the cool Sagrada Familia way), with dust and workers about, and there's very little to see. There's a small museum up some narrow stairways that has church artifacts and English commentary on how they were restored. That's about it, so you ain't missing a thing if you don't pay to go inside. I'm sure in a couple of years the Matthias Church will rank with the world's greats. Until then, admire the exterior only, especially the beautiful roof tiles. Oh, and buy your Budapest postcards here, as they were only 80 HUF compared to 200-300 HUF for the ones on the street.

Outside - beautiful, Inside - building site (but still worth visiting!). The outside of Matthias Church is beautiful and well worth a visit - stunning roof tiles and within a lovely area of Buda. We had to buy full price tickets to go inside which did seem outrageous as you couldn't actually see half the building as it was being renovated. However, the little museum at the top of the church was absolutely lovely and definitely worth seeing. Would be a shame to miss this if you're in Budapest!

Worth the visit. We visited Matyas Church (their spelling) on Easter Day and decided to go in for the noon service. The interior was gothic but with art deco designs on the columns and walls. The priest was very elderly and had to sit for some of the service but he was ably assisted. The servuce was entirely in Hungarian and there was little that translated for us. The exterior of the church alone was worth the visit whcih is part of a walk throught the castle district. The roof of the church is made from colored tiles and the tower is majestic. There are walkways overlooking the city giving specacular views of pest and the churches below.This is a necessary part of the castle hill trip whcih should be strolled over at least a half day. We took 3/4 of the day exploring the area.

If you like cathedral... Then necesary visit.. Really nice, big and spectacular cathedral, free entry, in same are many coffes and pedestrian street.... Without dubt a necesary ponit for visiting in the town.

Undergoing Massive Renovation - Very little visible at present. Although the majority of the church was partitioned off for massive renovations, we were able to get a glimpse of the inside of the church. From the little we saw, I would say "average", but the small museum had several restored pieces with great descriptions, so therefore the "very good". I would love to come back and see it when fully renovated - but it seems like that may be quite some time. The ticketing woman gave us tickets at the student price since the renovations obstructed so much.
A stroll in the castle is a must. And if you're up there step inside the Matthias church - it has a lovely calm and dimly lit interior, just as it should have/
Beautiful. A beautiful exterior unfortunately the inside is under renovation and not a lot can be seen, but it is worth a visit
Don't visit. Work in progress in the inside of the church. There is nothing special to look at for 1000 HUF.
don't bother to get inside the church. beutifull when you look at it but do not waste your money to get in because it is under reconstruction.
Church? No, reconstruction site.. Outside it is admired by flocks of tourist. Inside it is under reconstruction. The entrance fee was absolutely wasting of money. We spent there less than 5 minutes.
Beautiful. Old, colorful, and serene. But crowded with tourist groups. Go early or late.

Church with a Signature Roof!. The Matthias Church sits on the Castle Hill next to the Fisherman's Bastion. It is still under renovation, however, we managed to get some nice photos especially from the Fisherman's Bastion. During the Turkish occupation, it was transformed to a mosque for a while. It is named after the King Matthias and previously, it is more of a gothic church, however, after a few reconstruction and expansion, it exhibited more neo-gothic style currently. The roof is a special feature of this church, with multicoloured painted tiles to complement the church. Due to time constraints, we did not visit the inner part of the church but we were already mesmerized by the exterior.

Under construction. The outside is amazing but the inside is completely under construction and so not worth going in. It will be incredible once its finished but in the meantime take in the view outside.
In Buda. Wonderful old church - Under total reconstruction but should be done by 2012 summer. Incredible relics
Picturesque. Inside and out a lovely building in a picturesque setting

Beautiful architecture and sight to see. While the church was undergoing construction, we were still quite happy with the ability to wander through at our own pace and take pictures and very happy to see the construction, since this was such a sacred place. We even lit a candle and said a prayer at the altar. We thoroughly enjoyed this visit.
Okay. This church was nice but undergoing refurbishment at the time I visited so that was a little disappointing. I am sure it is better when it is fully open
Roof is amazing. Right next to the Fisherman's bastion, the ceramic tiled roof is great to see, good restaurants in the area and the views are a must
Wow !. From the architecture of the structure to the details in the rooftop...well worth a visit. We visited on a day where the sky was blue which made a fabulous backdrop for our photos.

beautiful Turkish architecture in downtown Budapest. High on Castle Hill, sits the gorgeous Matthias Church. It's only a few euros to get inside, and well worth it. Mosaics cover the walls and ceiling, and the feeling you get is quite mystical. I loved it.
Outstanding. The beauty of European churches, never cease to amaze me. This one, I will never forget. once inside, you feel the atmosphere of past worshipers and today's tourists...
It took so long. Well, It's still on the process of remodeling on outside. But I fianally got in there. It's beautiful art nuevo decoration inside. bit smaller than my thought.
Brilliantly restored Curch!. The experience of the beautiful interiors can be heightened if you hear any singing performance or a mass in Latin. Not to be missed.
worth from the outside but .... Expensive, crowded, and not much to see inside. There used to be historical flags hanging inside, where are they? Instead visit the Basilica.

Beautiful Historical Church. St. Matthias Church with its frilly Neo-Gothic spire and colorful ceramic tiles on the roof is breath-taking. Its slender main spire can be seen from many parts of the city.The church is ancient and very lovely and definitely worth visiting. It has some Moorish elements from the time when the Turks occupied it and turned it into a mosque. It has some lovely frescoes, a beautiful Rose window, and some outstanding stained glass windows.Matthias was crowned king of Hungary in the church and his two weddings were also held here. The church hosted several coronation ceremonies, royal weddings and baptisms and witnessed many turbulent events of Buda.Fisherman's Bastion and the Plague Column are on either side of the church. One can get to the church from the Pest side by taking a bus to Holy Trinity Square which is very close to the church.

Gorgeous architecture. Matthias Church is a beauty to behold - and we didn't even go inside! There was a private function for veterans-so we enjoyed the exterior. Nearby Fishermen's Bastian offers gran views-be sure to take a look!

Enchantingly Beautiful Cathedral. ****actually went for my honeymoon January 20-February 3, 2008***** Part of the church was under renovation-seemed a lot of churches go through fairly constant restoration, but considering their ages, it's understandable. Still, while the outside lacked the picturesque quality of, well, the pictures, the inside was hauntingly epic, with the only light shining though ancient stained glass, candles, and a few stray Christmas lights. Definitely a must see while in Budapest, and located right near huge Hilton and Fisherman's Bastion.
Matthias. Very beautiful both day and night. The acoustics are amazing. Well worth going to 10:00 mass there on a Sunday.
Very nice church. The architech was nice. it was very beautiful. I recommend to everyone,
Painted church. Get there early to enjoy the church in peace before the City Tours arrive. A spectacular painted interior adjacent to the Fishermans Bastion.

Gorgeous. Top 3 places to see in Budapest. The roof has a beautiful tile pattern and the church is very well maintained. It also is next to the fisherman's bastian that has the most incredible view of the parliament building.

A Fabulous Monument of Hungarian History. This church holds a special place among the many beautiful churches in Budapest. For me, this is the most interesting architectural structure in Hungary because of its stark white exterior crowned with tiles and spires and the rich, ornate interior that absolutely dazzles. If you have a chance to hear an organ concert (especially some Liszt), then do not miss out on the chance. Unforgettable.

Beautiful Church. We didn't have enough time at this lovely church - we arrived around 4:30 and it was closing at 5:00pm. The history is very interesting and a replica of the Virgin Mary statue that surprised the Turks at the end of their occupation of Hungary was beautiful. The exterior, especially at night is stunning, but the interior is worth a look as well - especially if you are a history buff and like old churches.

Stunning interior. St Mathias church is in the heart of the Castle Area opposite Fisherman's bastion. Do pay to go inside as the achitechture is breathtaking. You can go upstars and get great views of the high altar.

Love the Roof Tiles. I have been to many churches in Europe and after a while, they may look and feel the same. However, for the Matthias Church, I enjoyed the exterior of the church as I love the colourful roof tiles. The intricate painted interior would also be a sight to behold! To head up the Royal Palace District, you can take the furnicular up the hill and then find your way to the Matthias Church. Please wear modest clothing (covering shoulders and thighs) when visiting our church. Male visitors are requested to enter with bare head - unless this is against the rules of their religion. From the Matthias Church, you can head to Fisherman's Bastion to have a paranomic view of the Danube River as well as the Pest side of the city which is at the opposite side of the river. If you would like to sample Hungarian Wines, you are a walking distance to the House of Hungarian Wines. The walk in the Royal Palace District is very pleasant. Many sights to see and interesting cafes for you to have ashort rest.

My all times favourite visit. I like this church better than the St Steven's Basilica, it's a truly breathtaking church. There is a 990 Ft entrance fee, but it's totally worth it. You cannot go up into the tower though, that's too bad.

interesting history. As several reviewers have noted, European churches are often spectacular and ornate and yes .. after a while they can sort of all blend together as one hits 'church overload.' I like to choose my church visits based on history, and this one has it ...Budapest's first parish church, once a mosque when the city was captured by the Turks (who whitewashed the frecoes), restored several times (with deliberate attempts to adhere to the original 13th century plans in many cases), the coronation church of Frank Josef and Sisi ... it's all here for the historian in all of us. Double the pleasure when you can enjoy the beauty and history in one setting.

A must see. I've seen many churches all around Europe, in many different times. Hardly you'll get to see any one like Mathias Church. The inner walls are completely painted in a way that they look like tapestries. Each corner has some especial art work waiting to be seen and photographed. This church is now one of my favorites as it is the Sans Sang church in Brugge and the Notre Dame de Fouvière in Lion.

Superb.. This is an absolutely stunning church adjacent to the Hilton Hotel and (maybe rather over-rated) Fishermen's Bastion on the hill in Buda. The exterior is notable mainly for the colored tiles on the main roofs, but it is the interior which is stunningly beautiful. Every square inch of wall and pillar is decorated. It's clearly undergoing some sympathetic restoration. For such an amazing sight in July it was not too crowded (you do have to pay an admission fee, and many things in Budapest are not cheap). Worth going to Buda and maybe even Budapest just to see this.

Unique church. After traveling a lot in Europe, you get a little "churched out". But this one is definitely unique and worth seeing. The interior is Hungarian, not Baroque. Really beautiful and detailed painting of every surface inside. Much different than any other I have seen.
Different church. Love this church, outside and inside. The colours and drawings are amazing.

i like this church. touring europe for 3 months you get a little sick of church after church and paintings of christianity, etc.but i really liked this one. the art was a little different. it felt medieval and somewhere in between the plain stone of the huge gothic cathedrals and the over-the-top ornateness of the baroque churches.i thought it was cool & a little different than other old churches i've seen. also, admission is not too expensive which is nice.

Historic location in denial about its own history. Other reviewers have pointed out that this is a beautiful church but not as remarkable, architecturally, as others in Budapest. But it is, historically, the coronation church of the Hungarian kings; this is what makes it remarkable. Having read about the last Habsburg coronation, in 1916, in Miklos Banffy's "The Phoenix Land", I went there hoping to see some tangible evidence of that occasion in the form of displays, maybe even photographs, or at least a book about the occasion in the gift-shop - but apart from a couple of brief references on interpretarive panels, nothing. Many historic locales in Budapest seem to be in denial about their Habsburg heritage - I just didn't expect this, of all places, to be one of them.That said, still a beautiful building and a remarkable place; take Banffy's book with you and picture the scene as you look round.

Another neat church. I thought this church was just so-so. I guess I've seen so many churches (and we went to St. Stephen's that morning) that this one didn't impress me all that much. The neat thing was that the walls were all painted with different pictures and scenes and seeing that was neat and different from what is normally in historic churches. Right now there is a lot of construction on the outside, they are replacing the roof (which is really beautiful). Also the inside painted areas seemed like they needed touchups and repair as well. I don't remember how much it was to get in (I read somewhere else that it was 600 ft each, $4 each). I read somewhere about replicas of crown jewels, but I don't remember seeing any of that. There were a few pictures of things to the right, and a little gift shop, but no real museum. The main hall was quite pretty and it was nice to sit down for a bit. The wood carvings on things were interesting to see. But bottom line, it's probably not on my 'must do' list. My husband would disagree because he thought the paintings were amazing.

A different look at churches in Europe. If you've travelled extensively in Europe, this church is a definite must-see. The walls inside are painted, giving the church a very different feel than other churches in the region. This is where the coronation of Franz Joseph and Sisi who ruled the Austro-Hungarian empire took place, giving history buffs a nice link across the historical empire. Definitely read about the "crowning" of the Virgin Mary both here and at St. Stephens Basilica for an interesting look at religion and state.

Undergoing renovation - still worth a looksee!. The church is undergoing major reconstruction, repairing damage, incurred during WW2, to the bell tower.The parts open to visitors are well worth 800HUF, the atmosphere is pleasant (ignoring the drill & hammer noises).
